title: Suicide of an Uber engineer: Widow blames job stress
author: Carolyn Said
pullQuote: But his time at Uber turned into a personal tragedy, one that will compel the ride-hailing company to answer questions before a judge about its aggressive work culture.

title: Zoom Acquires Keybase and Announces Goal of Developing the Most Broadly Used Enterprise End-to-End Encryption Offering
author: ERIC S. YUAN
pullQuote: We are excited to integrate Keybase’s team into the Zoom family to help us build end-to-end encryption that can reach current Zoom scalability.

title: Google affiliate Sidewalk Labs abandons Toronto smart-city project
author: JOSH O’KANE
pullQuote: Google affiliate Sidewalk Labs is walking away from building a smart-city development in Toronto after two and a half years of controversy over its origins, overreach, and privacy and financial implications.

title: Clearview AI Has Promised To Cancel All Relationships With Private Companies
author: Ryan Mac, Caroline Haskins, and Logan McDonald
pullQuote: Facing numerous lawsuits, the New York startup said it "is cancelling the accounts of every customer who was not either associated with law enforcement or some other federal, state, or local government department, office, or agency.”

title: This Script Sends Junk Data to Ohio’s Website for Snitching on Workers
author: Janus Rose
pullQuote: An anonymous hacker wrote a script to sabotage Ohio's 'COVID-19 Fraud' website, which allows companies to report employees and prevent them from collecting unemployment insurance.

title: DESPITE SKYROCKETING UNEMPLOYMENT, TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY PLANS TO OUTSOURCE HUNDREDS OF FEDERAL JOBS TO OVERSEAS COMPANIES
author: Rachel M. Cohen
pullQuote: AS DONALD TRUMP vows to save the economy amid the global pandemic, while the number of Americans filing for unemployment has skyrocketed to 30 million, the Tennessee Valley Authority, or TVA, the nation’s largest government-owned power provider, has announced plans to outsource 20 percent of its highly-skilled technology workforce to Capgemini, CGI, and Accenture — companies based in France, Canada, and Ireland respectively.

title: Want a Green New Deal? Start by Protecting the Tennessee Valley Authority
author: FRED STAFFORD
pullQuote: The Tennessee Valley Authority is one of the New Deal’s greatest achievements: a publicly owned utility with a large, unionized workforce right in the heart of America. But now it’s under threat.

title: TVA moves to outsource IT jobs, tells Chattanooga center workers to expect layoff notices by June
author: Dave Flessner
pullQuote: The Tennessee Valley Authority told IT workers at its Chattanooga computer center Tuesday that they should receive layoff notices by June as TVA moves to outsource some of its computer and software development jobs to outside contractors.

title: Utility Breaks Union Contract by Outsourcing IT Work
author: DAVE FLESSNER
pullQuote: One of the biggest labor unions representing workers at the Tennessee Valley Authority claims the federal utility is violating its own contracting guidelines and potentially weakening its cybersecurity by laying off TVA computer software specialists in Chattanooga, Tenn., and turning the work over to a French-based contractor.

title: Hearst Loses Big at the National Labor Relations Board
author: Sarah Jones
pullQuote: The National Labor Relations Board ruled against each objection it raised to the bargaining unit proposed by the WGAE and ordered a union election. It’s a total loss for Hearst, made doubly resonant by the fact that conservatives currently control the NLRB — the company couldn’t have designed a version of the NLRB more likely to rule in its favor, and it still lost.

title: The Battle Between Google Engineer James Damore and Google Is Over
author: Jody Serrano
pullQuote: Ex-Google engineer James Damore and Google asked a California judge this week to dismiss a lawsuit brought by the enginer against the company. The lawsuit alleged that Google discriminated against conservative white men.

title: The Making of the Tech Worker Movement
author: Ben Tarnoff
pullQuote: The walkout didn’t come out of nowhere: Google in particular and the tech industry in general were already in the midst of a wave of rank-and-file mobilization. And, while the walkout remains exceptional for its size, this wave has continued to grow. Tech workers are engaging in collective action at a range of companies, around a range of issues. A tech worker movement is taking shape.

title: Leaving Amazon
author: Tim Bray
pullQuote: May 1st was my last day as a VP and Distinguished Engineer at Amazon Web Services, after five years and five months of rewarding fun. I quit in dismay at Amazon firing whistleblowers who were making noise about warehouse employees frightened of Covid-19.

title: TWC Newsletter Issue 1: How do we help each other?
pullQuote: Learning about how we’re all connected and building relationships to make positive change across the industry is a slow but necessary process. This is why we need to stay in the struggle, together.

title: Big Tech Won’t Save Us: The Case for Social Transformation over Coronavirus Surveillance
author: Movement for Anti-Oppressive Computing Practices
pullQuote: Surveillance and structural inequality go hand-in-hand; in the era of coronavirus it will be no different.

title: NSO Employee Abused Phone Hacking Tech to Target a Love Interest
Amazon locks down internal employee communications amid organizing efforts
Facebook deletes event for stay-at-home protest in Michigan
author: Justin P. Hicks
pullQuote: The Facebook event page for an upcoming protest against extending Michigan’s state of emergency was deleted by Facebook’s staff for defying the government’s guidance on social distancing.

title: I Never Planned to Be a Front-Line Worker at Dollar General
author: Kenya Slaughter
pullQuote: No barriers, not enough staffing, low wages. They seem to not know there’s a danger to employees.

title: A Brief History of the Gig

Explainer: How to control women's sexual health with tech

ICE cold: Microsoft's GitHub wrings hands over US prez's Trump immigration ban plan
How the Coronavirus Could Create a New Working Class
Kickstarter plans layoffs after new projects on the site drop off by 35 percent
author: Ashley Carman
pullQuote: Kickstarter announced in an internal memo today that it’s likely going to lay off employees. CEO Aziz Hasan writes that the crowdfunding company has already seen a significant drop in crowdfunding projects being listed on the site, which is how Kickstarter makes its money. Projects are down by about 35 percent, the memo states, with “no clear sign of rebound.”

title: Amazon-owned Whole Foods is quietly tracking its employees with a heat map tool that ranks which stores are most at risk of unionizing
author: Hayley Peterson
pullQuote: Amazon-owned Whole Foods is tracking and scoring stores it deems at risk of unionizing, according to five people with knowledge of the effort and internal documents viewed by Business Insider.

title: We Need a Robust CBC Now More Than Ever
author: Paris Marx
pullQuote: At a time when Canadians are eager to know what is happening in their communities, particularly with regard to the spread of COVID-19, these cuts are the opposite of what we should be seeing. And the government’s response has not been reassuring: it has launched a $30 million ad buy in order to replace some of the revenue that is being lost from private advertisers, but that will only prop them up for so long.

title: America Is About to Witness the Biggest Labor Movement It’s Seen in Decades
author: Steve LeVine
pullQuote: It took 40 years and a pandemic to stir up a worker revolution that’s about to hit corporate America

title: Cards Against Humanity Bought Clickhole
author: Katie Notopoulos
pullQuote: The card game company purchased the comedy website from G/O Media in an all-cash deal, transforming ClickHole into a majority employee-owned company.

pullQuote: An employee-led group says an SEC proposal would discriminate against smaller investors and employees awarded company stock.

pullQuote: When all you have is a hammer all your problems look like nails

pullQuote: The last two years have witnessed a wave of walkouts, petitions and other workplace actions at video game and tech companies.

title: SoftBank-Funded Zume Reportedly Lays Off 80% Of Staff
author: Natasha Mascarenhas
pullQuote: In a little over a year, pizza-making robot startup Zume has gone from getting $375 million from SoftBank, to pivoting to food packaging through an acquisition, to raising at a reported $4 billion valuation, to its latest: laying off 80 percent of its employees, as reported by Business Insider.

title: Silicon Valley is primed for a worker uprising
author: NICOLE KARLIS
pullQuote: The foundation was laid in the 2010s. Will the 2020s be defined by Tech's labor struggles?

title: i feel organizing priorities are the same today as yesterday
author: @jessfromonline
pullQuote: those conditions aren't coincidental or inevitable. it is because we lack those institutions. we can build them. we can build power.

title: Neuroscience proves what we’ve suspected all along: The reason we hate our jobs is… capitalism.
author: Arash Kolahi
pullQuote: Despite all the reasons we to love to work: the feeling of pride from a job well done, mastery of art or craft, our need for social esteem, or fulfillment that comes from creating something of social value, for all that gives us meaning in our work, we sure do hate our jobs! 2/23

pullQuote: Amazon founder Jeff Bezos warned Saturday that America will find itself “in trouble” if the leadership of large tech companies decide not to work with the Pentagon.

pullQuote: Secretive data analytics company Palantir is working on Project Maven, the US Department of Defense program that Google dropped in March following protests inside of the company, according to people familiar with the project.

pullQuote: To feel safe while making risky deliveries, workers are more likely to depend on each other than company staff on a hotline.

author: Kathryn Spiers
pullQuote: My name is Kathryn Spiers. I was at Google for just under 2 years. I worked on the Platform Security team, focusing on Chrome’s use within Google. Part of my job was to write browser notifications so that my coworkers can be automatically notified of employee guidelines and company policies while they surf the web.

title: Security engineer says Google fired her for trying to notify co-workers of right to organize
author: April Glaser
pullQuote: “I was doing nothing more than notifying my co-workers about Google's obligations under labor law,” Kathryn Spiers, the former Google engineer, said.

title: Labor board rolls back employee email rights after Google recommendation
author: Colin Lecher
pullQuote: The federal labor board ruled this week that employers can block workers from using email to organize, in a decision that companies, including Google, have asked for.

title: Spadework: On political organizing
author: ALYSSA BATTISTONI
pullQuote: Graduate school, I came to realize, was not the place to go to learn about politics.

title: Companies Can Ban Use of Work Email in Union Organizing
author: HASSAN A. KANU
pullQuote: Businesses can ban workers from using company email for union and other organizing purposes, the National Labor Relations Board decided in a Dec. 17 decision.

pullQuote: Apple, Google, Microsoft, Dell, and Tesla are being sued over their alleged reliance on cobalt mined by children.

pullQuote: Seoul court convicted Samsung's Lee Sang-hoon and 24 others of labor violations.

pullQuote: Claire Stapleton didn't just buy into the lore of Google—she helped write it. What happened when the bard of Google became one of its most vocal critics?

author: Rodrigo Ochigame
pullQuote: How Big Tech Manipulates Academia to Avoid Regulation

title: Among the most pervasive lies about capitalism is how capitalism rewards workers.
author: Arash Kolahi
pullQuote: As we will prove, these lies are just propaganda with NO basis in reality. (Thread 1/30

title: Google's holiday gift to Devin Nunes
author: Judd Legum
pullQuote: Nunes' antics during the impeachment hearings capped a year when he filed six defamation lawsuits, seeking hundreds of millions in damages from Twitter, a GOP political operative, media companies, a retired farmer, and a fictional cow. The suits were all filed by an attorney, Steven Biss, whose law license was suspended twice by the state of Virginia. In response, Google quietly rewarded Nunes' behavior with a check for $5000 to help him get reelected.

title: Thousands of Google’s cafeteria workers have unionized
author: Shirin Ghaffary
pullQuote: Around 2,300 contracted workers who serve meals to Google employees in the San Francisco Bay Area have unionized, saying they’re overworked and underpaid.

title: The Babysitters Club

pullQuote: Apps like Seamless and Yelp listen in on our adult lives, then speak to us like children.

title: The 100 Worst Ed-Tech Debacles of the Decade
author: Audrey Watters
pullQuote: Oh yes, I’m sure you can come up with some rousing successes and some triumphant moments that made you thrilled about the 2010s and that give you hope for “the future of education.” Good for you. But that’s not my job. (And honestly, it’s probably not your job either.

title: Work-Life Balance Couldn’t Fix My Burnout
author: Frankie Nicoletti
pullQuote: Burnout is like carpal tunnel. It creeps in and causes pain. Ignore it and the symptoms worsen. A wrist brace or a break from the keyboard may temporarily alleviate the discomfort but you have to make lifestyle changes to completely get rid of it. You have to change the way you type.

title: Starbucks is offering new mental health benefits, but employees are demanding different kinds of support
author: Kate Taylor
pullQuote: 'We didn't ask for a meditation app, we want to be able to pay our rent'.

title: Facebook Is a Crime Scene: “The Great Hack” Documentary Details Big Data’s Threat to Democracy
author: Jehane Noujaim, Karim Amer, Brittany Kaiser, Emma Briant
pullQuote: As new details emerge about how the shadowy data firm Cambridge Analytica worked to manipulate voters across the globe, we continue our look at the documentary, “The Great Hack.” We speak to Cambridge Analytica whistleblower Brittany Kaiser, the film’s co-directors Jehane Noujaim and Karim Amer, and the propaganda researcher Emma Briant.

title: Alphabet’s Top Lawyer to Retire Following Questions on Conduct
author: Mark Bergen
pullQuote: Drummond was accused of violating workplace relationship rules. Company veteran denied wrongdoing; makes way for new leaders

author: APRIL GLASER
pullQuote: Even in the famed computer science program, students are no longer sure they’d go to work for Facebook or Google (and definitely not Palantir).

author: By J. David Goodman
pullQuote: The hotel workers’ union has become one of the most feared political forces in New York.

title: Instacart Workers Are Calling for a National Boycott of the Grocery Delivery App
author: Lauren Kaori Gurley
pullQuote: “I don’t believe there’s another gig economy company with workers who are more pissed.”

author: Lauren Kaori Gurley
pullQuote: On Monday afternoon, workers in Pikeville, Kentucky halted a 120-car train carrying their employer’s coal. Some workers say they’re owed $3,000.

title: CAA: Microsoft boss calls India's new citizenship law 'sad'
pullQuote: The India-born executive said what is happening is sad and he would love to see a Bangladeshi immigrant succeed in the country's technology industry.

title: Investing In Immigrant Surveillance: Palantir And The #NoTechForICE Campaign
author: Morgan Simon
pullQuote: Today, 14.7% of the Department of Homeland Security’s $47.5 billion 2019 budget is dedicated to contracts with companies that can provide an increasingly valuable commodity: information technology.

title: How to Organize Your Workplace Without Getting Caught
author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai and Lauren Kaori Gurley
pullQuote: Do you want to protest your company’s crappy record on sexual harassment? Are you thinking of unionizing? Here’s the Motherboard Guide to Secure Labor Organizing.

title: Teaching Assistants Say They’ve Won Millions from UC Berkeley
author: Lauren Kaori Gurley
pullQuote: The university underemployed more than 1,000 students—primarily undergraduates in computer science and engineering—in order to avoid paying union benefits, UAW Local 2865 says.

title: A CHEATSHEET FOR COMPARING ORGANIZING MODELS
author: Marianne Garneau
pullQuote: Across these different forms, you will often see the same tactics deployed: petitions, delegations of workers marching on a target with a demand, picketing or flyering, bad publicity, etc. Therefore, it is difficult to get an appreciation for the differences between these campaigns and organizations on the basis of their tactics alone.

title: The Silicon Valley Economy Is Here. And It’s a Nightmare.
author: LIA RUSSELL
pullQuote: Low pay, soaring rents, and cities littered with e-scooters. Welcome to the future.

title: Former Top GitLab Lawyer Fired as Company Moves Towards IPO
author: Brian Baxter
pullQuote: GitLab Inc. earlier this month fired a top lawyer linked to its former compliance chief, who left the company claiming “discriminatory and retaliatory behavior.”

title: RPI students form group to hold tough conversations about tech
author: Michael Williams
pullQuote: Students from the Silicon Valley to the Hudson Valley say there's been a lack of conversation in their classrooms about the potential pitfalls and social implications of technology, and the morally dubious tasks some of the more well-known — and well-paying — tech companies may ask them to perform as employees.

title: The Secretive Company That Might End Privacy as We Know It
author: Kashmir Hill
pullQuote: A little-known start-up helps law enforcement match photos of unknown people to their online images — and “might lead to a dystopian future or something,” a backer says.

title: How Airbnb Deals With Crime
author: The Journal
pullQuote: After a deadly mass shooting, Airbnb faced questions about how much responsibility it has for safety at the properties listed on its site. WSJ's Kirsten Grind investigates Airbnb's efforts to fight crime on its platform.

title: Joe Biden calls game developers little creeps who make titles that teach you how to kill
author: Rob Thubron
pullQuote: A hot potato: Politicians rarely have anything good to say about video games, and former US vice president Joe Biden is particularly unimpressed by the industry, calling developers he met at the White House “creeps” and “arrogant” who make games that teach people how to kill.

title: Biden tells coal miners to learn to code
author: Alexandra Kelley
pullQuote: The 2020 presidential hopeful advises coal miners to move into new industries — but it’s not that simple.

pullQuote: Truly, what could be more insidious and dystopian than a Peter Thiel-backed startup — co-founded by Rudy Giuliani’s former aid — that combines A.I. and facial recognition to help cops match photos of unknown people to their photos scraped from Facebook and other social media sites? Obviously, without their consent.

title: Unmasking a Company That Wants to Unmask Us All
author: Kashmir Hill
pullQuote: I wanted to learn as much as I could about Clearview AI, including who was behind it and how the app worked, to help readers understand this groundbreaking tool.

title: The IRS Decided to Get Tough Against Microsoft. Microsoft Got Tougher.
author: Paul Kiel
pullQuote: The story is different for taxpayers who aren’t represented by a battalion of attorneys and CPAs, Chin said: “In my opinion, we hammer the little guys and we let the big guys go.”

title: The nightmare, tempered
author: Devika Daga
pullQuote: In recent months, in pursuit of a new career path towards tech policy, I’ve taken an interest in the work of Congress. In particular, I sought to understand what tools Members of Congress and their staff have in conducting their oversight and legislative functions. After all, it’s one thing to complain about a dysfunctional industry and demand regulation, but it’s another to want to help build that regulation.

title: “With Great Tech Comes Great Responsibility.”

pullQuote: The Mozilla Foundation has just released a wonderful guide, titled “With Great Tech Comes Great Responsibility: A student guide for navigating ethical issues in the tech industry.”

pullQuote: Amazon is the rumored tenant of a newly approved air cargo facility that working-class residents say would bring more dead end jobs and air pollution to their community.

title: Inside hundreds of surveillance experiments along the US-MX border
author: marcdacosta
pullQuote: Dozens of defense contractors are testing out new surveillance technologies along the US-Mexico border. By examining thousands of broadcast licenses filed with the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), the scale of this activity comes into view. This repository provides a guide for exploration. You can examine the FCC License data yourself, track radio license activity on a map, or dive into the specific defense companies that are prototyping new ground radar systems for detecting bodies and drones.

pullQuote: Two officials from the local Iron Workers union pleaded guilty today for their role in a brutal assault on a group of non-union ironworkers in Dyer, Indiana. title: Garbage Language: Why do corporations speak the way they do?
pullQuote: So with every exchange, you have to acknowledge a reality where words like optionality and deliverable could be just as solid as blimp and pretzel. What happens if you ask a Megan or a Steph Korey or an Adam Neumann what they mean? I imagine a box with a series of false bottoms; you just keep falling deeper and deeper into gibberish. The meaningful threat of garbage language — the reason it is not just annoying but malevolent — is that it confirms delusion as an asset in the workplace.

pullQuote: Major nonprofits and other organizations have pledged millions of dollars toward groups trying to build a modern trust-busting movement.

title: How To Unionize Your Workplace
author: Another Slice
pullQuote: Don't watch this on a workplace computer or phone! Also, don't substitute this for face to face organizing trainings, such as the OT101 by the IWW.

title: Target Workers Unite: Statement on the 'United For Respect' Organization
author: Target Workers
pullQuote: We, the workers of Target, were extremely disillusioned with these repeated promises, backpedaling, and changes of mind. We were always thanked for “being flexible” and for understanding that U4R was in a “period of transition.” Frankly, we’ve never known U4R to not be in a “period of transition,” an apparent excuse to justify backdoor maneuvering that undermines our rank and file efforts. This is why we launched Target Workers Unite.

title: When Elon Musk Tried to Destroy a Tesla Whistleblower
author: Matt Robinson, Zeke Faux
pullQuote: It started with a Twitter meltdown and ended with a fake mass shooter. A former security manager says the company also spied and spread misinformation.

title: Leaked Video Reveals Amazon's Belligerent Anti-Worker Tactics
author: Jake Johnson
pullQuote: As Amazon works to combat its public image as a starvation-wage employer by doling out mere pennies in pay hikes and deploying an army of workers to sing the company's praises on Twitter, a video leaked on Wednesday revealed that the trillion-dollar company is continuing to work feverishly behind the scenes to crush any attempts by workers to unionize and bargain collectively for better wages and working conditions.

title: Data-Crunching Is Coming to Help Your Boss Manage Your Time
author: By David Streitfeld
pullQuote: A new generation of workplace technology is allowing white-collar jobs to be tracked, tweaked and managed in ways that were difficult even a few years ago. Employers of all types — old-line manufacturers, nonprofits, universities, digital start-ups and retailers — are using an increasingly wide range of tools to monitor workers’ efforts, help them focus, cheer them on and just make sure they show up on time.

title: Postscript on the Societies of Control
author: Gilles Deleuze
pullQuote: Felix Guattari has imagined a city where one would be able to leave one's apartment, one's street, one's neighborhood, thanks to one's (dividual) electronic card that raises a given barrier; but the card could just as easily be rejected on a given day or between certain hours; what counts is not the barrier but the computer that tracks each person's position--licit or illicit--and effects a universal modulation.
